head.title: 21 September / 2 October 1708. – Translation of a letter from [the Envoy Extraordinary of Great Britain to Russia,] Mr. [Charles] Whitworth to [the head of the Ambassadorial Chancery,] Count [Gavrila Ivanovich] Golofkin, about the affront offerd to [the Russian representative in London,] Mr. [Andrei Artamonovich] Matveoff

note.bibl: TNA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-5, f. 96-99. English translation.

div.p: Translation of a letter from Mr. Whitworth to Count Golofkin, about the affront offerd to Mr. Matveoff

Last night I received the honour of your Excellencys Letter of the 16.th Inst[ant] concerning the Extraordinary affront offer’d to His Excellency your Ambassador Mons[iue]r Matveoff in London, and the great concern of His Czaarish Majesty: I am very confident and dare give you the most positive assurances, that H[is] C[zarish] M[ajesty] himself cannot be more moved at this unluky accident, than the Queen is, and that nothing shall be last undone which lyes in Her Majestys power, to let all the world see Her resentement on this occasion; and to convince His Majesty of the great Esteem She has, and allways will have for his person and friendship; the annext copys of the two Letters from his Excellency the Secretary of State M[iste]r Boyle to your Ambassador which I received two days ago by a Courier from Archangel, express the sentiments of the Court so fully on this occasion, that it is not possible for me to find out Terms more strong or more oblidging; you will there see what that seventeen persons are allready in prison, and will be prosecuted with the outmost severity for this attempt: I own it is of such a nature that I shall not endeavour any wise

to excuse their insolence; but I must observe, that the Ambassadors Relation seems to be aggravated in so violent a manner, as is not usuall to persons of his prudence and moderation, who instead of endeavouring to lessen the friendship of their Principals, should soften the report of such inconveniences as may some times arrise throu the ignorance or ill manners of inconsiderable people: as Her Majestys Ministers could not expect to unkind a representation, after the many Civilitys he had received from them and all persons of quality and Distincion, they have not taken the precaution to give me a full information of the particulars; however I shall write for one, and do not question but that will clear the Court from several imputations; In the mean time I shall onely observe, that his Excellency M[iste]r Secretary Boyle in no less than three Letters positively mentions his having sent Secretary to take care of the Ambassador, and get him released, as soon as ever he had notice of it, thou very late at night; which is very far from the unworthy suspicion of M[iste]r Walpooles coming of his own accord to divert himself at such a misfortune: I also find by several private Letters to me and other persons here, that the Ambassador was not carryed to prison, but to the house of the Bailif, that not onely two but above ten Tradesmen, who are now in prison, ware concern’d in arresting him for debts, which ware much greater than he mentions, thou I cannot tell the particular sum; nor do I find nor can believe, that ever any public notice

was given, or day appointed to pay his creditors ; for it is unreasonable to think any people should be so mad as to run themselves into these inconveniencys, when a time was named and they inform’d they should receive satisfaction; which particulars I do not mention to excuse the fact, but onely to let you see, that some persons, who do not wish well to the peace of both crowns, have tacken taken pains to give His Exc[ellence] Mons[ieu]r Matveoff as bad impression of this matter as ever they would.

You will see by the inclosed copys that your Ambassador was leaving great Britain, and His Exc[ellency] the Secretary Boyle informs me, that he had declar’d to receive a very valuable present from Her Majesty, to make use of a Yacht for his Transportation, or even to take his recredentials, notwithstanding all possible diligence was using, according to the course of our Laws, for making reparation, and his presence would have been very agreable till the wholle was effected; for my part I shall immediately give Her Majesty an account of your desires & by my representations heartily contribute all that lyes in my power, towards procuring a suitable satisfaction, and maintaining the old friendship between the two Dominions of Great Britain and Great Russia; hoping at the same time your Exc[ellence] will endeavour, as you ware pleased to promiss, to moderate by your good officies His Czarish Maj[esty] resentement and facilitate the way on your side; if I thought my presence might be acceptable or of use to this good work; I hall willingly wait

upon His Cz[arish] Maj[esty] and your Exc[ellence] with a great deal of pleasure, at any time and place you may think fit to appoint me, both to give by word of mouth the further assurances of Her Majestys great concern at this affair, and to deliberate on the most proper means for bringing it to a [one word i] for conclusion; and Her Majesty has even under consideration if it be demanded to send person of quality express to His Cz[arish] Maj[esty] as a further proof of Her Esteem.

From all what I have here related I hope you will own such case is taking for suitable and speedy reparation, that you have no reason to think of any other method, or to impute this unluky accident, which could not possibly be foreseen and therefor not prevented, to Her Majesty or the Government, much less to let it have any impression on the present friendship and good Correspondence between the two Crowns; which I hope is built upon more solid principles, than to be shaken by such occasions, considering the vast benefits that daily accrue and still may increase to this Empire from that of Great Britain; and as to Her Majestys Friendship and strength, it is too much valued in most places of Europe to be slighted, especially in the present juncture, when you must be sensible, that many people would gladly lay hold for any occasion, to make a breach or even a coldness between the two Crowns; but that, I am fully persuaded, as long as His Cz[arish] Maj[esty] has such prudent Councillors as you are, will never happen and on the other side I shall allways do my best, to

find out opportunitys, whereby the Czar may be induc’d to encrease the Esteem he has often profess’d to me to have for Her Majesty, and that gracious regard He has hitherto shown for Her Subjects, by whom he has several times own’d he is well serv’d.

After having detain’d Your Excellency thus long I shall be very short in those points, which relate to me and the Consul; which thou it is true are not to be compared with the great affront unlukely happen’d to M[iste]r Artemonowitz, yet have been of weight and might have been of more, if ill represented; and as to the satisfaction obtain’d, I am oblig’d to say it has never been without a great deal of pains and disagreableness, and then not proportionable to the affronts: as for the people that attack’d me and my servants with stones, they knew very well who I was, for my Equipage was not so common as not to be easily distinguish’d, and my servants nam’d my character several times ; that the stones did not hit me was my good look luck and not their good manners, for they ware indifferently fluny [?], and two offer’d to lay hoe’d on my bridle, and had my horse given way to them, I cannot tell how they might have treated me then : as to their hard bodily punishment it was the commonest in this Country, and then taken barely pro formû, my secretary onely permitting them to have four of five blows, and that from the two alone, who would have seized my horse, thou above twenty ware concern’d in the uproar; as to my goods being seal’d up,

I had not acquainted your Precasse with the place whither I sent them, because I left servants in Town to take care of them, they being onely laid in one of the Consuls warehouses to avoid fire and thieves, against which I had no other place of security ; nor could the Town Councill pretend ignorance whose they ware, since my servants appear’d there in my Livery, to acquaint them of it before they ware sealed up, and thou I represented this in Grodno, yet the seals were not taken off in some months, till after my arrival in Mosco : it is true a Consul can be brought into no Comparison with Ambassadors and Envoys, that is as to the rangs and other prerogatives, but the Laws of Nations also takes care for the protection of their persons, their houses and servants, nor did the two Instances I mention’d about M[iste]r Goodfellow Her Majestys Consul and Agent General any wise relate to his Trafick or the pretensions of her precauses might have on him; but ware particular affronts done to his house; but I avoid enlarging upon them, because they cannot help the present business and only might make it worse.

As to the Recognition of King Stanislaus, I find His Cz[arish] Maj[esty] takes most amiss, that it was done without giving him any previous notice, at a time his Ministers ware treating a nearer allyance. All that I can at present add to what I lately writ to your Excellency on this point, is, that t’is probable I may have had orders to make such a notification a considerable time ago, if all the secretary of

States Letters were come to my hands, but yours Exc[ellency] very well knows that near three months Letters from the 1. Febr[uary] to the last April are still missing nor have I yet received any duplicats of them by the present irregularity of the posts, so that I am entirely ignorant of all that was transacting at Court in that time.

I congratulate your Exc[ellency] once more on the happy success of your arms, and wish the continuance thereof may crown all your endeavours; for I am certain, Her Majesty the Queen will have a very great satisfaction in every thing which may contribute to the wellfare of so good a friend and ally as She esteems His Cz[arish] Maj[esty]: it is with very particular pleasure that I give your Exc[ellency] these many assurances, to which I beg leave to add those of my being with great respect and Esteem
